inlineContent.text: The
CoreBluetoothMock
library provides an intuitive API for mocking physical
Bluetooth LE devices using an implementation in Swift. This allows:
Testing Bluetooth LE connectivity on a simulator,
Simulating a Bluetooth LE device during the development phase,
Reliable method for automating tests and taking screenshots.
Current version supports testing only central manager features.
The peripheral manager functionality is planned.
To make migration from
CoreBluetooth
to
CoreBluetoothMock
easy the API of the
library was designed to similar to the native one. Only a few changes are required,
most of them involve changing or removing the
statement, not the
application code.
The migration can be done in one of 2 ways:
Copy
file from the
Example app
to your project.
This file contains number of type aliases for all
types and renames them to
therfore removing the not need to perform any changes in your code.
Remove:
in all your files, as the types are now defined locally in the project.
In all files using
CoreBluetooth
replace
with
Replace all instances of
with
Due to the fact, that the library provides two different implementations of
there is a difference, comparing to the native API, how the manager is initialized. Instead of:

code: let manager = CBCentralManager(delegate: self, queue: ..., options: ...)

inlineContent.text: you need to use the

code: let manager = CBMCentralManagerFactory.initiate(delegate: self, queue: ..., options: ..., forceMock: ...)

inlineContent.text: The last parameter,
, when set to
, allows to run the mock implementation
also on a physical device.
The
provides two implementatons of
The native implementation proxies all requests to the
CoreBluetooth
framework.
When the code runs on a simulator (or the
parameter was set) a mock manager
is created. Instead of physical devices, this manager interacts with mock implementations,
defined as
. Such peripheral specification should emulate the actual
behavior of a real device as close as possible.
To create a mock peripheral use
. This method returns a
instance which can set up advertisements and connection behavior.
Any number of such specifications can be defined.
Sample code:
Such mock peripherals must be added to the simulation using
From that moment simulated advertising starts and the device can be scanned or retrieved
just like physical devices.
A mock peripheral may advertise with:
static data with a fixed advertising interval,
one-time
advertisements (
set to 0),
Both types of advertisements can be delayed using the
parameter.
The initial advertising configuration is set up using
which can be called multiple times, if required.
The advertisement data can be changed during the simulation using
The
or
methods allows to specify a
. This object defines the behavior of the
mock peripheral, how will it respond to Bluetooth LE requests, a hard reset, etc. The implementation
should mimic the behavoir of the real device as much as possible to make the tests reliable.
To test how the app handles connection interruptions, the mock connection can be terminated using
or
with parameter
- simulates a situation when another app on the iDevice
connected to this peripheral. The device will stop advertising (unless
flag was set) and will be available using
- simulates a connection error.
- simulates device hard reset. The central will notify
delegates 4 seconds (supervision timeout) after the device has been reset.
- simulates moving the peripheral close or away
from the device.
- simulates sending a notification or indication
from the device. All subscribed clients will be notified a connection interval later.
- simulates change of the advertisemet data
of the peripheral. The peripheral will stop advertising with previous data and start with the new set.
- simulates caching the device by the iDevice.
Caching pairs the device’s MAC with a random identifier (UUID). A device is also cached whenever
it is scanned. Caching makes the device available to be retrieved using
- simulates the device changing its MAC address.
The iDevice will not contain any cached information about the device, as with the new MAC it is
considered to be a new device.
- creates a simulation with given list of mock
peripheral. This method should be called when the manager is powered off, or before any
central manager was initialized.
- this method should be called before any central
manager instance was created. It defines the initial state of the mock central manager.
By default, the manager is powered off.
- turns on the mock central manager.
- turns off the mock central manager.
All scans and connections will be terminated.
- sets the state of all currently existing central
managers to
and clears the list of managers and peripherals bringing
the mock manager to initial state.
- this closure will be used when you initiate a
central manager with
option. The map returned will be
passed to
callback in
central manager’s delegate.
- this closure will be used to emulate Bluetooth
features supported by the manager. It is available on iOS 13+, tvOS 13+ or watchOS 6+.
- simulates the current authorization state
of a Core Bluetooth manager. When any value other than
is returned, the
will change state to

is a
protocol
, the KVO features are not available. See

inlineContent.text: CoreBluetooth

abstract.text: features in your app using mocks.
The following objects can be used to create mock implementation of Bluetooth LE
devices. Such mock peripherals will be available using
Keys used to pass options when initializing a central manager.
Keys used to pass state restoration options to the central manager initializer.
Keys used to pass options when connecting to a peripheral.
Keys used to pass options when scanning for peripherals.
Keys used to specify items in a dictionary of peripheral advertisement data.
Values representing the connection state of a peripheral.
Mock implementation of
A Boolean value that specifies whether the system warns the user if the app instantiates
the central manager when Bluetooth service isn’t available.
An array of solicited service UUIDs.
A dictionary that contains service-specific advertisement data.
A representation of common aspects of services offered by a peripheral.
A characteristic of a remote peripheral’s service.
Simulates a change in the advertising packet.
A stub
implementation designed only for SwiftUI Previews.
Makes the device connectable, and also marks already connected
by some other application. Such device, if not advertising,
can be obtained using
An object that represents a remote device.
Mock implementation of
An object that scans for, discovers, connects to, and manages peripherals.
A protocol that provides updates on the use of a peripheral’s services.
A live L2CAP connection to a remote device.
Simulates the current authorization state of a Core Bluetooth manager.
An array of service IDs for use when restoring state.
An array of UUIDs found in the overflow area of the advertisement data.
A Boolean value that specifies whether the system should display an alert when
connecting a peripheral in the background.
A Boolean value that specifies whether the system should display an alert for any
notification sent by a peripheral.
A protocol that provides updates for the discovery and management of peripheral devices.
This delegate should implement the behavior of a real Bluetooth LE device duting a connection.
Values that represent the possible properties of a characteristic.
A universally unique identifier, as defined by Bluetooth standards.

For apps that opt-in to state preservation and restoration, this is the
first method invoked when your app is relaunched into the background to
complete some Bluetooth-related task. Use this method to synchronize your
app’s state with the state of the Bluetooth system.
